rev.comment: removed "Reverse-engineering issues with Windows", I just think it does not belong here
rev.diff:
Line 283: Line 283:
Concern about Chrome's optional usage collection and tracking have been noted in several publications.<ref>{{cite news |first=Elise |last=Ackerman |title=Google browser's tracking feature alarms developers, privacy advocates |url=http://www.mercurynews.com/breakingnews/ci_10510989 |publisher=Mercury News}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://news.cnet.com/8301-13860_3-10031661-56.html?tag=txt |title=Google's Omnibox could be Pandora's box |date=2008-09-03 |accessdate=2008-09-04}}</ref> On 2 September 2008, a [[CNET]] news item<ref>{{cite web |url=http://news.cnet.com/8301-17939_109-10030522-2.html | title=Be sure to read Chrome's fine print |publisher=[[CNET]] |accessdate=2008-09-03}}</ref> drew attention to a passage in the terms of service for the initial beta release, which seemed to grant to Google a license to all content transferred via the Chrome browser. The passage in question was inherited from the general Google terms of service.<ref>[https://www.google.com/accounts/TOS?hl=en Google Terms of Service]</ref> On the same day, Google responded to this criticism by stating that the language used was borrowed from other products, and removed the passage in question from the Terms of Service.<ref>{{cite web |title=Google Chrome Terms of Service (English) |url=http://www.google.com/chrome/eula.html?hl=en |accessdate=2008-09-04}}</ref> Google noted that this change would "apply retroactively to all users who have downloaded Google Chrome."<ref name=license-change>{{citation |title=Google Amends Chrome License Agreement After Objections |url=http://www.pcworld.com/businesscenter/article/150637/google_amends_chrome_license_agreement_after_objections.html |publisher=[[PC World (magazine)|PC World]] |date=2008-09-03 |accessdate=2008-09-03}}</ref> There was subsequent concern and confusion about whether and what information the program communicates back to Google. The company stated that usage metrics are only sent when users opt in by checking the option "help make Google Chrome better by automatically sending usage statistics and crash reports to Google" when the browser is installed.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.google.com/chrome/intl/en/privacy.html |title=Google Chrome Privacy Notice |accessdate=2009-10-27}}</ref>
Concern about Chrome's optional usage collection and tracking have been noted in several publications.<ref>{{cite news |first=Elise |last=Ackerman |title=Google browser's tracking feature alarms developers, privacy advocates |url=http://www.mercurynews.com/breakingnews/ci_10510989 |publisher=Mercury News}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://news.cnet.com/8301-13860_3-10031661-56.html?tag=txt |title=Google's Omnibox could be Pandora's box |date=2008-09-03 |accessdate=2008-09-04}}</ref> On 2 September 2008, a [[CNET]] news item<ref>{{cite web |url=http://news.cnet.com/8301-17939_109-10030522-2.html | title=Be sure to read Chrome's fine print |publisher=[[CNET]] |accessdate=2008-09-03}}</ref> drew attention to a passage in the terms of service for the initial beta release, which seemed to grant to Google a license to all content transferred via the Chrome browser. The passage in question was inherited from the general Google terms of service.<ref>[https://www.google.com/accounts/TOS?hl=en Google Terms of Service]</ref> On the same day, Google responded to this criticism by stating that the language used was borrowed from other products, and removed the passage in question from the Terms of Service.<ref>{{cite web |title=Google Chrome Terms of Service (English) |url=http://www.google.com/chrome/eula.html?hl=en |accessdate=2008-09-04}}</ref> Google noted that this change would "apply retroactively to all users who have downloaded Google Chrome."<ref name=license-change>{{citation |title=Google Amends Chrome License Agreement After Objections |url=http://www.pcworld.com/businesscenter/article/150637/google_amends_chrome_license_agreement_after_objections.html |publisher=[[PC World (magazine)|PC World]] |date=2008-09-03 |accessdate=2008-09-03}}</ref> There was subsequent concern and confusion about whether and what information the program communicates back to Google. The company stated that usage metrics are only sent when users opt in by checking the option "help make Google Chrome better by automatically sending usage statistics and crash reports to Google" when the browser is installed.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.google.com/chrome/intl/en/privacy.html |title=Google Chrome Privacy Notice |accessdate=2009-10-27}}</ref>
â   â
===Reverse-engineering issues with Windows===
  â   â
On 11 September 2008, a few days after the release of Chrome's source code, [[Scott Hanselman]] noticed a comment in Chrome's code saying "You can find this information by disassembling Vista's SP1 kernel32.dll with your favorite [[disassembler]]."<ref name="Hanselman">
  â
{{cite web
  â
| last = Hanselman
  â
| first = Scott
  â
| title = The Weekly Source Code 33
  â
| url=http://www.hanselman.com/blog/TheWeeklySourceCode33MicrosoftOpenSourceInsideGoogleChrome.aspx
  â
| accessdate = 2009-01-07
  â
}}</ref>
  â
[[Ars Technica]] published an article asking, "[http://arstechnica.com/articles/paedia/chrome-antics-did-google-reverse-engineer.ars Did Google reverse-engineer Windows?]" Google later denied disassembling Vista and referred to previous public discussion of the undocumented APIs that Google used.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.cnet.com/8301-1001_3-10046395-92.html|title=Google denies disassembling Vista software|accessdate=2009-02-09|date=2008-09-19|publisher=[[CNET News]]|author=Stephen Shankland}}</ref>
